description: From Medieval Latin seraphicus, from Late Latin seraphīm, seraphīn, from Hebrew שָׂרָף‎ (saráf, “seraph”). Surface etymology seraph +‎ -ic.

adjectives.description: seraphic (comparative more seraphic, superlative most seraphic)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to a seraph or the seraphim.
examples: the Seraphic Doctor, title given to the Italian medieval theologian Bonaventure

A thousand times he was like to have denyed all, but durst not defame the most sacred Idol of his Soul: Sometimes he thought his Uncle would be generous, and think it fit to give him Silvia; but that Thought was too Seraphick to remain a Moment in his Heart.
